review_title: Great mission but poor leadership and toxic work culture
pros:
Mission of the organization is great
Work is complex. Opportunity to work in a start up environment.
cons:
Poor leadership- leadership has no direction or care for people and their development
No career pathways- once you are in a role, you don't know what to work towards next. 
Toxic work culture- lot of talk about well being but internally nothing done, employees face burn out, racism, sexism, unnecessary aggression from leadership- made to feel guilty and unsafe when complains are made

pros: One of the best charity organisations I have worked for, they care about their staff and wellbeing is a priority. The learners are at the forefront of what they do with a mission that is valuable in society
cons: not really a con depending on preference - its mainly work from home model which I like

pros: It was ok, gained a lot
cons: It’s unclear how long you need to be involved with them after it ends

review_title: Good mixture of people and process driven organization
pros: - Great colleagues - People centric management -fast pace of work - Emphasis on employee welfare
cons: working across timezones can cause irregular daily schedule however, there is a flexibility to plan your day as per individual comfort.

pros: Good employer. Average gross salary
cons: High employee turnover and poor medical cover

job_title: Information Technology Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Team members were awesome and mission is great!
cons: Management is bloated outdated and frankly clueless.

review_title: Very helpful to start a career as data analyst
pros: There are many peoples to help you to find a job.
cons: For our batch, we didn't get a good technical tutor.

pros: All-round 10 out of 10.
cons: To be honest, nothing possible to say, besides I would've liked it to be a hybrid bootcamp, since mine was all remote, but nonetheless 10/10.

review_title: No consistency whatsoever & the mission is not the forefront of the work.
pros: - getting to work with some big name companies - flexibility - set out to do a good thing but depending on the country, some are good at working towards the mission and some are not - and have a long way to go to get there.
cons: - systems are all over the place - very focused on funding and bums on seats rather than focusing on the quality of the learners - no consistent volume employer partner for some tech cohorts, but management don’t care and just expect placements to happen. - tell staff they’re not micromanaging when they in fact are - not a lot of movement within the company & pay isn’t amazing.

pros: Cares about the staff welfare and wellbeing
cons: Currently there is nothing I have discovered

pros: compensation & benefits are as per Industry Norms
The cause seems valuable however, the recruitment process is very poor and it does not reflect what they aim to do as a charity
cons: I have recently applied and I have to create a very long cover letter and going through a pre-recorded interview which I found very unusual. After investing time and resources in this process you don't hear from them although I tried to ask for a feedback . I think it's very badly organised considering that they are working with vulnerable categories, they are very unprofessional and that fact that they do not provide a feedback says a lot.

pros:
Well paid for a charity
Mission looks good on paper
cons:
There’s definitely a mould for successful employees here and if you don’t fit it you won’t fit in
Not enough members in the team to do everything, they expect too much from the people they do have leading to burnout
Always trying to reinvent the wheel - if it isn’t broke, don’t fix it
Spreading people really thin - they started with tech programmes and has started branching out into too many areas with the staff picking up the pieces and getting hammered by senior management if it doesn’t work as planned

pros: Innovative and truly global culture
cons: Pace of work can veer towards unsustainable

pros: Great people to work with,
cons: Just went through significant layoff of employees. In financial trouble from what little they told us. Told on Wed, out on Fri.

pros: loved it, best thing ever happened to me
cons: none, enjoyed ever min of it

pros: Assisting for people to enter in Tech field
cons: They are already doing great work

pros: There is a Good Work-life balance
cons:
Pay may not be standardized
The culture is very wanting

pros: Clear impact for graduates at the end of the programme
cons:
Poor senior leadership who care more about the "bums on seats" than on the learners
Poor work environment everyone is overworked and stressed but leadership is doing nothing to change it
Driven by what the employers/industry wants and not what the candidates need

pros: Non, it’s basically a cult
cons: Everything, it’s all just really sus and expensive

pros:
As a disclaimer, I can only speak about the US presence and not about other countries. There are a few great things about working at Generation:

1) Most, if not all, of the staff are nice people who joined to advance an important mission. 

2) If you're lucky, you might see significant advancement through some of the frequent re-organizations. People who were brought in by the CEO or by one of his close reports get regular title and salary increases. Those outside of the 'inner circle' are rarely as lucky.

3) Thanks to some lucky breaks with funders, Generation is becoming more recognized in the space. It's not as prominent as a Year Up or a Per Scholas, but Generation's built more brand recognition than it had in the early days.
cons:
1) Pure startup chaos. Although Generation is a six-year old organization, the day-to-day is more like you'd find at a one or two-year old organization. Systems and processes are nowhere near where they should be, teams don't communicate well, and many staff don't have a clue about the big picture.

2) Lots of people have been placed into roles that they're not qualified for. Generation does a good job of trying to retain talent as re-orgs happen every 6-12 months. The flip side is that a lot of staff don't seem happy in their roles (ones they were not hired for) or are in over their heads.

3) Reckless growth trajectory. The CEO made "ambitious" promises to attract a massive funder that the organization does not seem capable of delivering on. Instead of focusing on program quality before scaling, Generation has promised to enroll an unrealistic, ever-increasing number of students each year. While ambition is great, the numbers aren't realistic in the context of how many people enroll in bootcamps across the country and how many competitors there are. Eventually donors are going to notice and pull funding. 

4) Weird culture. Lots of Jesus talk in a secular nonprofit. There's a culture of toxic positivity across the organization that makes asking even simple questions risky. Just a weird place all around.

pros: mission-driven, incredibly talented and dedicated team, remote work with flexible schedules, global social impact, good benefits
cons: long hours and sometimes challenges with burnout

review_title: Recruitment at Generation UK= idea mining and getting free labour
job_title: Manager of Data and Operations in London, England
pros: Org sounds great "on paper." Noble mission.
cons: Recruitment excercise carried out at Generation UK can be likened only to a scam. I quit at stage 5 when advised there might be "two more tasks to complete and one more interview" - at which point I already completed two tasks, an online assessment and two interviews. The tasks they throw at people are very involved (the task I completed required creation of a candidate assessment model form scratch, complete data field review, choose candidates for them and document all of this.) You are kindly informed what you submit is for "public consumption" hence the org will have no problem using a candidate's model or its derivative in its business operations going onwards.

job_title: Senior Instructional Coach in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros: You get to work with international network, get to lead our support dynamic new projects.
cons:
-less structures more of exploration mode
-quite manual

pros: Awesome team with a true desire to help youth find employment through quality training.
cons: Very corporate environment obsessed with data.

pros: Flexible schedule, internal promotions, little accountability, ongoing growth and change to improve.
cons: Little accountability, young and inexperienced upper management, too focused on making the major funders satisified, don’t ask for feedback from staff on the ground, slow turnaround, poor infrastructure.

review_title: Training and Development org run by business consultants
pros: Mission is admirable; really amazing folks doing stellar work on the ground
cons: Leadership has limited experience in the education and training space; some instances of valuing partners and timelines rather than high quality training and participant support

cons: Work is tough, bad weather, water is clean
